AGENTS.

The Presidents Message, SO promptly issued D.
you, is most masterly document. 1t breathes ths
feeling of heart tenderly sensible TO the bouneous
gifts of Providence, and indicates a mind vigllan
and discerningi in the guardianship and management
of the affairs of the Nation. Its style is smooth, CO.
pious and perspicuous and its language '' express
slve, energetic and refined" 1t has disappointed
none but the calumnous misguided Editors and lea
ders ufthe Opposition These, Mr.. Adams has COM
pleteIy dlscomfted, nasmuch as he has entirely re-
Trained from touching any topic which the contend
ing parties are discussing. The writer's of the OPP
position were couched like erocious tigers in their
lairs, " nursing their wrath" ready at the stated
moment to attack without justice or reason, their
devoted victim. But Mr. Adams has left them no
chance, and has entirely asted their sanguine pre-
dictions g that his message would he fine elec-
tioneerng Message )" and in consonance with his
unwavering conduct in such matters he has used no
argument or art, to foresta public opinion a des-
ideratum wished for, and affected by the Combna-
tion There are no false accusations, as in Bcver-
ley's letter, no anuendoes Gen. Jacksons, and
no hes as in the East Room story but all IS dis
passionate and candid review ofnatonaf concerns, III
which every patriotic citizen must feel an interest
and satisfaction. Mr. Adams, like true Republi-
can will follow the dictates of the people, in his tu


ture as he has in his former course: and pledges
hinselfto their interests and wishes in the following
explicit words " amidst the multiplicity OF topics
/ of great national concernment which may recon-


mend themselves to the calm and patriotic de-


lberatons of the Legislature, it may suffice to say


that in those and all other measures which may re-


ceive their sanction my hearty cooperation Will DC
given, conformably to the duties enjoned upon me


and under the sense of all the obligations prescribed
by the Constitution Who could ask more

OF twenty years Of triumph becausehis gov
ernment was so modelled that with hi'n every
thing must be swept away, and that a reaction
proporoned to the violence Of the action must burst
forth at once both within and without. The mania
of conquest had reversed the state of things in Eu
rope; we, the eldest born of liberty and lndepen-
dence, sping our blood in the service OF roy
al passions against the cause of natons and out:ag
ed nations we're turning round upon US, more terri
BILE from being armed with the principles which we
had forsaken.


cat times, this immense mass Of passion which
he was accumulating against him, this multitud
Of avenglng arms ready to be raised, filled his an
bilious spirit with involuntary apprehensIons. Look
ing around him, he was alarmed to find himself sol
tary, and conceived the idea of Strengthening h
power by moderating it.-Then it was that n
thought OF creating hereditary peerage and re-
constructing his monarchy on more secure found'
tions. But Napoleon without illusion to tn
bottom of things. The nation, wholly and cor
tinually occupied in prosecuting the designs OF n
Chief had previously not had time to form any plan
for ITSELF The day on which it should have ceas
ed to be stunned by the din Of arms, it would have
called itself to account for its servile obedience l.
is BETTER thought he, for absolute prince to fight
foreign armies than to have struggles against the Ell


ergy of the citizens. Despotlsm had been organic


ed for making war war was continued to uphol


despotism. The die was cast ; France must eithe


conquer Europe, or Europe subdue France,
s Napoleon fell he fell, because, with the mel


of the nineteenth century, he attempted the wori


OF an Attila and Genghis Khan because he gay


the rens to an imagination directly contrary to tn


spirit of his age, with which, nevertheless, his reas


on was perfectly acquainted because be would no


pause on the day when he felt conscious OF his ina
bility to succeed. Nature has fixed boundary


beyond which extravagant enterprises cannot be cal


ri 10 a EmnecO
reached in Spain, and he overleaped il in Russia
Had he then escaped destruction, his nieAlble pre-
sumption would have caused him TO find elsewher
, Babylon and Moscow

. Humorous account of Penn'a Battalion Day,

Solomon Greenty.-At the last Court ofOyer and
Terminer, for Kent County, this man was indicted
convicted and sentenced to Death for burning the
Jail of that county. The day before that assigned
for his execution, the Governor pardoned him, upon
The condition of has Leaving the state We don't up
hold this part Of the case, and much wish it had been
omitted and hope it may not be drawn INTO Prece-
dent. For very obvious reasons snch cohn'lon IS
not allowable. 1t is deeply to be regretted that any
alloy was permitted to be mixed with measure
which has done so much honor to our GOVERNOR
We have none of those mawkish feelings, which
cannot bear, upon any occasion, the lnillcton OF
capital punishment: nor are we disposed to lind
fault with the apprehension that many, entertain,
that the pardonins power may be too freely exer-
cised


Within very few years back this county had
was not very remote from those of the State House
and other public buildings, which were in lmnedi-
ate connection with the body of the town. little
before one o'clock, on Sunday mornings the citizens
For the Delaware Journal.

RECEIPT FOR couRTsHIP.
Two or three dears and two or three sweets;
Two or three balls and two or three treats
Two or three serenades given as lure,
Two or three oaths how much they endure
Two or three messengers sent in one day,
Two or three times led out to play,
Two Or three soft speeches made by the way;
Two or three tickets for two or three times,
Two or three love letters writ all in rhymes
Two or three months keeping strict to these rules
Can never fail making couple Of fools.
TUESDAY, December Ill, 1927.

e2d November last, from the stable of the subscri-

md there, summoned the inhabitants to the specta
lie. Here was no laundering OF engines as in our
,ities--no bustng of fremen-for there were no
engines. no fremen, no ladders, no buckets and no
water The flames, as they burst from the roof, or
poured out from the iron grated windows, and curl
ed and fingered about the walls, making the whole
fabrick one bright mass of fire, rendered egible
every expression in the countenances OF the SUR
rounding crowd of men, women and children-some
with and some almost without clothes. 1t was not
pryate property that was making the brilliant bon
fire. Each would sustain loss, but the cummuni-


y Of suffering, and the exemption from an over
,.helming individual infction, was rather matter
# delight than Of terror and regret. Not breath
Of wind was stirring, except what gently inclined
the volume of flame, in the only direction, in which
it would endanger no other public, or private pro-


ery If from accident the fire arose, every one thank
I'd Providence, that the sacred sanctuaries OF do
nestle peace and happiness were likely to remain
anscathed. If the work OF an incendlary-of some
napess tenant Of the house of woe, trusting his libe


alton, less to the consciousness of his own inno-
aence than to the terrible agency he had invoked,


here was voice in the gentle wind that blew, that


allied in behalf of the culprit, for something like


forgiveness, and almost for emotion ut gratitude
1t was the morning of the Sabbath. That passed,
,he sterner duties Of the following day commenced.
Judges attorney general. grand and petty Jurymen,
all arrived from various parts OF the state and coun-
~ were seen surrounding the smoking ruins. These
are hard times, and the people who had been So re-
Gently called upon for the funds expended, in the
erection Of this building, were now again to be tax
I'd for its reconstruction Is wonderful that there
became Immediately associated, in almost every


mind with the rksome and unpleasant undertaking,
another and cheaper public work OF eYpia0n and


atonement Amidst such feelings, what spirit


what talents, short of superhuman, could have walk


I'd with and protected innocence herself, through


the ordeal that followed The humanity OF the


court assigned distant day, for carrying into execu-


ton, the dreadful sentence of the law. This short
interval of life soon passed, and apparently


passed with nothing of reentance in thepublic mind.


Tie voice of the multitude seemed still. most nexo


rably to call for the execution of this unhappy man.


The governor was supposed to taulter. and some


blood thirsty spirits-nO, not some, only One--a
law drunken beggar, who would himself have dis


sraced the gibbet, threatened TO erect galows IN


front of the State House, and to burn the governor


himself in eiigy. On what seemed to general e1


pectation the last day but one OF the poor Wretchs


life he in whose hands, on these occasions the law


has placed the issues of life aud death, arrived at the


seat of governe Mt. Never the exercise, not OF


humanity, nor of clemency, but OF stern duty, more
solemnIy called for TO have left this case where
the court and the Jury had left ito have permit


ted the law to have taken its course was, to all ap-
T pearance, to have gone on smoothly and safelys
, with the current of public opinion. On the other
hand to lenghen out the days of this man, was to
: resolve to stem a most furious torrent--to draw
down upon himself the execrations of men blinded
0 and nfuriated. Overlooking. nobly overlooking all


bearing of these matters upon himself, our Governor,
: with virtuous independence that did nm immortal
: honor determined to do what he believed ntrlnsl-
d cally right He stood firm and unmoved, amid the
angry coverings, which seemed gathering for his de-
struction; did his duty earessiy Of all consequences
It and as il Providence intended to reward his honor
i and Independence, it became, almost Immediately
afterwards KNOWN that strong and virtuous reac-
ton had even then, taken place IN the public mind.
g There had been, from the first small stili voice
IS raised against the execution OF this man-but was


no more than the coong of the dove to the roaring OF
the ocean, 1t was not the voice of friend or relative
fnr nor friend nor relative had he Better days had
= nassed over his head--but they were with many
e !. winters snow" 1t was from beyond the limits
of our own county, that the voice OF reason began
d first to make itself heard. In the Borough OF IL


minpton whose citizens no less distinguished


for their enlightened good sense, than their we'll re-


guIated humanity, meeting was called, and a me-


mortal in favor of pardoning Greeny, was signed by
n considerable number of the most respectable peo-
nile of the place. In the cities Of Philadelphia and
q New York, where our public journals had carried,
d amid the news of the day, the intelligence OF our
n disaster and of the doom passed upon the cuiprlt
), from behind the counters OF their merchants-from


the work benches of their mechanics, the citizens
= and traders of our county, had to endure homes
i which sent them home with juster views and more
. uenernus feelings. s.Whatn' said they to peo
Ene." build your gaos, in spirit of mean parslmo-
: nv, with temptations to your prisoners to break
h them, and then hang the poor wretches who have
Il fallen into the snares you have yourselves set TOR
4 them Try them, too, amid the hot embers OF the


ruins. and hang them before the smoke has done rise
. ing to Heaven, in Judgment against you !! what


do YOU compare. in turpitude and deep crlmnallty,


the effort Of u wretch, to release himself from i'm

Can never fail making couple Of fools.


BONAPARTE.
The annexed sketch of the warrior talents of Ma
poleon, and Of the causes Of his downfall, is from
Gen. Foy's history of the Peninsula war.


sWth his passions and in spite of his errors, Ma
poleon is, taking him all in all, the greatest warrior
of modern times. He carried into battle stoical
courage, profoundly calculated tenacity, mind
fertile in sudden inspirations which by unhoped for
resources Disconnected the plans of the enemy. Let
us beware Of atributing long series of success to
the organic power of the which he set in mo-
ton. The most experienced eye could scarcely dis
cover in them any thing but elements OF disorder.


Still less let it be said that he was successful
captain because he was mighty monarch. or all
his campaigns the most memorable are, the cam
pagn of the Adige, where the general of yesterday,
commanding an army by no means numerous. and
at first badly appointed. placed himself at once
above Turenne and on level with Frederick ;-and
the campaign in France in l8 a. when, reduced to
handful of harrassed troops, he combatted force
of ten times their number. The last flashes Of the
imperial lightning still dazzed the eyes OF our enc
mics and it was fine sight to see the bounds of
the old lion. tracked, hunted down, beset, present
ing lively picture of the days of his youth. when
his powers developed themselves in the fields oi
carnage.


| "Napoleon possessed. in an eminent degree
the faculties requisite for the profession of arms
temperate and robust. watching and sleeping at
pleasure, appearing unawares where he was least
expected he did not disregard details to which i'm
portant results are sometimes attached. The hand
which had Just traced rules for the government ol
many millions Of men would frequently rectify an
incorrect statement of the situation of regiment,
or write down whence two hundred conscripts were
to be obtained, and ON what magazine their shoes
were to be taken A patient and easy interlocutor
he was home questOner, and he could listen j;
rare talent in the grandees of the earth. he car
ried with him into battle a cool and impassab
courage never was mind deeply medtative
more fertile in rapid and sudden illuminatons.-
On becoming Emperor he ceased not to be the sol
dier. If his activity decreased with the progress
age, that was owing to the decrease OF his physlca
powers.


.'In games of mingled calculation and hazard
the greater the advantages which man seeks t
obtain, the greater risks he must rum 1t is precise
ly this that renders the deceitful science OF con
querors SO calamitous to nations. Napoleon, thoug
naturally adventurous, was not deficient in cons


tencvor method and he wasted neither his soldier
nor his treasures where the authority OF his nam
: sufficed. What he could obtain by negotiations
by artifce, he required not by force of arms. III


sword, although drawn from the scabbard, was nj
al stained with blood, unless it was impossible to
d tain the end in view by manguvre. Always rel
y dy to fight. he chose habtuay the occasion and II
4 ground Out Of fifty battles which he fought,he WI
: the assailant in at least forty


"Other generals have equalled him in the art


disposng troops on the ground. Some have GIVE


battle as well as he did ; we could mention sever


who have recevedit better but IN the manner


directing an offensive campaign he has surpass'
all.


"The wars in Spain and Russia. prove nothl


in disparagement Of his genius. 1t is not by q


rules of Montecuculi and Turenne, manGuyrlns


the Renchen, that we ought to Judge OF such ente


prises. The first warred to secure such or SUI


winter-quarters the other to subdue the world


frequently beloved him not merely to gain battl


but to gain ii in such manner as to astound Euro


and to produce gigantic results. His political vie'


were necessarily interfering with the strategic gel
~ us and to appreciate him properly we must n
- conne ourselves within the limits of the art OF wa
ny This art is not composed exclusively OF technlc
details it has also its philosophy. To find in I'll
mt elevated region rival to Napoleon, must go bal
ss to the times when the feudal institutions had n


yet broken the unity Of the ancient nations. III


founders of religions alone have exercised ov
their disciples an authority comparable with tn


which made him the absolute master of his arm


This moral power became fatal to him, because
he strove to avail himself of it even against the asce
RI dency of material force. and because it led him
be despise positive rules, the long violation Of whie
de will not remain unpunished.


nv "When pride was hurryng Napoleon towards b
r., fall, he happened to say: France has more need


me than l have of France He spoke the trut


But why had he become necessarily Because


had committed the destiny Of the French to Il
- chances of an interminable war; because, in spin
I'D of the resources oits genius, rendered ds
st ly more hazardous by his stalking the whole OF II
he force and by the bodne of his movements, risk


in every campaign in every battle, the frui

convicted and sentenced to Death for burning the
Jail of that county. The day before that assigned
for his execution, the Governor pardoned him, upon
The condition of has Leaving the state We don't up
hold this part Of the case, and much wish it had been
omitted and hope it may not be drawn INTO Prece-
dent. For very obvious reasons snch cohn'lon IS
not allowable. 1t is deeply to be regretted that any
alloy was permitted to be mixed with measure
which has done so much honor to our GOVERNOR
We have none of those mawkish feelings, which
cannot bear, upon any occasion, the lnillcton OF
capital punishment: nor are we disposed to lind
fault with the apprehension that many, entertain,
that the pardonins power may be too freely exer-
cised


Within very few years back this county had
was not very remote from those of the State House
and other public buildings, which were in lmnedi-
ate connection with the body of the town. little
before one o'clock, on Sunday mornings the citizens

A RECEIPT FOR couRTsHIP.
full articles.article:
RECEIPT FOR couRTsHIP.
Two or three dears and two or three sweets;
Two or three balls and two or three treats
Two or three serenades given as lure,
Two or three oaths how much they endure
Two or three messengers sent in one day,
Two or three times led out to play,
Two Or three soft speeches made by the way;
Two or three tickets for two or three times,
Two or three love letters writ all in rhymes
Two or three months keeping strict to these rules
Can never fail making couple Of fools.

JOSEPH CARR.
Dec. 6. 1897. 4tp

md there, summoned the inhabitants to the specta
lie. Here was no laundering OF engines as in our
,ities--no bustng of fremen-for there were no
engines. no fremen, no ladders, no buckets and no
water The flames, as they burst from the roof, or
poured out from the iron grated windows, and curl
ed and fingered about the walls, making the whole
fabrick one bright mass of fire, rendered egible
every expression in the countenances OF the SUR
rounding crowd of men, women and children-some
with and some almost without clothes. 1t was not
pryate property that was making the brilliant bon
fire. Each would sustain loss, but the cummuni-


y Of suffering, and the exemption from an over
,.helming individual infction, was rather matter
# delight than Of terror and regret. Not breath
Of wind was stirring, except what gently inclined
the volume of flame, in the only direction, in which
it would endanger no other public, or private pro-


ery If from accident the fire arose, every one thank
I'd Providence, that the sacred sanctuaries OF do
nestle peace and happiness were likely to remain
anscathed. If the work OF an incendlary-of some
napess tenant Of the house of woe, trusting his libe


alton, less to the consciousness of his own inno-
aence than to the terrible agency he had invoked,


here was voice in the gentle wind that blew, that


allied in behalf of the culprit, for something like


forgiveness, and almost for emotion ut gratitude
1t was the morning of the Sabbath. That passed,
,he sterner duties Of the following day commenced.
Judges attorney general. grand and petty Jurymen,
all arrived from various parts OF the state and coun-
~ were seen surrounding the smoking ruins. These
are hard times, and the people who had been So re-
Gently called upon for the funds expended, in the
erection Of this building, were now again to be tax
I'd for its reconstruction Is wonderful that there
became Immediately associated, in almost every


mind with the rksome and unpleasant undertaking,
another and cheaper public work OF eYpia0n and


atonement Amidst such feelings, what spirit


what talents, short of superhuman, could have walk


I'd with and protected innocence herself, through


the ordeal that followed The humanity OF the


court assigned distant day, for carrying into execu-


ton, the dreadful sentence of the law. This short
interval of life soon passed, and apparently


passed with nothing of reentance in thepublic mind.


Tie voice of the multitude seemed still. most nexo


rably to call for the execution of this unhappy man.


The governor was supposed to taulter. and some


blood thirsty spirits-nO, not some, only One--a
law drunken beggar, who would himself have dis


sraced the gibbet, threatened TO erect galows IN


front of the State House, and to burn the governor


himself in eiigy. On what seemed to general e1


pectation the last day but one OF the poor Wretchs


life he in whose hands, on these occasions the law


has placed the issues of life aud death, arrived at the


seat of governe Mt. Never the exercise, not OF


humanity, nor of clemency, but OF stern duty, more
solemnIy called for TO have left this case where
the court and the Jury had left ito have permit


ted the law to have taken its course was, to all ap-
T pearance, to have gone on smoothly and safelys
, with the current of public opinion. On the other
hand to lenghen out the days of this man, was to
: resolve to stem a most furious torrent--to draw
down upon himself the execrations of men blinded
0 and nfuriated. Overlooking. nobly overlooking all


bearing of these matters upon himself, our Governor,
: with virtuous independence that did nm immortal
: honor determined to do what he believed ntrlnsl-
d cally right He stood firm and unmoved, amid the
angry coverings, which seemed gathering for his de-
struction; did his duty earessiy Of all consequences
It and as il Providence intended to reward his honor
i and Independence, it became, almost Immediately
afterwards KNOWN that strong and virtuous reac-
ton had even then, taken place IN the public mind.
g There had been, from the first small stili voice
IS raised against the execution OF this man-but was


no more than the coong of the dove to the roaring OF
the ocean, 1t was not the voice of friend or relative
fnr nor friend nor relative had he Better days had
= nassed over his head--but they were with many
e !. winters snow" 1t was from beyond the limits
of our own county, that the voice OF reason began
d first to make itself heard. In the Borough OF IL


minpton whose citizens no less distinguished


for their enlightened good sense, than their we'll re-


guIated humanity, meeting was called, and a me-


mortal in favor of pardoning Greeny, was signed by
n considerable number of the most respectable peo-
nile of the place. In the cities Of Philadelphia and
q New York, where our public journals had carried,
d amid the news of the day, the intelligence OF our
n disaster and of the doom passed upon the cuiprlt
), from behind the counters OF their merchants-from


the work benches of their mechanics, the citizens
= and traders of our county, had to endure homes
i which sent them home with juster views and more
. uenernus feelings. s.Whatn' said they to peo
Ene." build your gaos, in spirit of mean parslmo-
: nv, with temptations to your prisoners to break
h them, and then hang the poor wretches who have
Il fallen into the snares you have yourselves set TOR
4 them Try them, too, amid the hot embers OF the


ruins. and hang them before the smoke has done rise
. ing to Heaven, in Judgment against you !! what


do YOU compare. in turpitude and deep crlmnallty,


the effort Of u wretch, to release himself from i'm

BONAPARTE.
The annexed sketch of the warrior talents of Ma
poleon, and Of the causes Of his downfall, is from
Gen. Foy's history of the Peninsula war.


sWth his passions and in spite of his errors, Ma
poleon is, taking him all in all, the greatest warrior
of modern times. He carried into battle stoical
courage, profoundly calculated tenacity, mind
fertile in sudden inspirations which by unhoped for
resources Disconnected the plans of the enemy. Let
us beware Of atributing long series of success to
the organic power of the which he set in mo-
ton. The most experienced eye could scarcely dis
cover in them any thing but elements OF disorder.


Still less let it be said that he was successful
captain because he was mighty monarch. or all
his campaigns the most memorable are, the cam
pagn of the Adige, where the general of yesterday,
commanding an army by no means numerous. and
at first badly appointed. placed himself at once
above Turenne and on level with Frederick ;-and
the campaign in France in l8 a. when, reduced to
handful of harrassed troops, he combatted force
of ten times their number. The last flashes Of the
imperial lightning still dazzed the eyes OF our enc
mics and it was fine sight to see the bounds of
the old lion. tracked, hunted down, beset, present
ing lively picture of the days of his youth. when
his powers developed themselves in the fields oi
carnage.


| "Napoleon possessed. in an eminent degree
the faculties requisite for the profession of arms
temperate and robust. watching and sleeping at
pleasure, appearing unawares where he was least
expected he did not disregard details to which i'm
portant results are sometimes attached. The hand
which had Just traced rules for the government ol
many millions Of men would frequently rectify an
incorrect statement of the situation of regiment,
or write down whence two hundred conscripts were
to be obtained, and ON what magazine their shoes
were to be taken A patient and easy interlocutor
he was home questOner, and he could listen j;
rare talent in the grandees of the earth. he car
ried with him into battle a cool and impassab
courage never was mind deeply medtative
more fertile in rapid and sudden illuminatons.-
On becoming Emperor he ceased not to be the sol
dier. If his activity decreased with the progress
age, that was owing to the decrease OF his physlca
powers.


.'In games of mingled calculation and hazard
the greater the advantages which man seeks t
obtain, the greater risks he must rum 1t is precise
ly this that renders the deceitful science OF con
querors SO calamitous to nations. Napoleon, thoug
naturally adventurous, was not deficient in cons


tencvor method and he wasted neither his soldier
nor his treasures where the authority OF his nam
: sufficed. What he could obtain by negotiations
by artifce, he required not by force of arms. III


sword, although drawn from the scabbard, was nj
al stained with blood, unless it was impossible to
d tain the end in view by manguvre. Always rel
y dy to fight. he chose habtuay the occasion and II
4 ground Out Of fifty battles which he fought,he WI
: the assailant in at least forty


"Other generals have equalled him in the art


disposng troops on the ground. Some have GIVE


battle as well as he did ; we could mention sever


who have recevedit better but IN the manner


directing an offensive campaign he has surpass'
all.


"The wars in Spain and Russia. prove nothl


in disparagement Of his genius. 1t is not by q


rules of Montecuculi and Turenne, manGuyrlns


the Renchen, that we ought to Judge OF such ente


prises. The first warred to secure such or SUI


winter-quarters the other to subdue the world


frequently beloved him not merely to gain battl


but to gain ii in such manner as to astound Euro


and to produce gigantic results. His political vie'


were necessarily interfering with the strategic gel
~ us and to appreciate him properly we must n
- conne ourselves within the limits of the art OF wa
ny This art is not composed exclusively OF technlc
details it has also its philosophy. To find in I'll
mt elevated region rival to Napoleon, must go bal
ss to the times when the feudal institutions had n


yet broken the unity Of the ancient nations. III


founders of religions alone have exercised ov
their disciples an authority comparable with tn


which made him the absolute master of his arm


This moral power became fatal to him, because
he strove to avail himself of it even against the asce
RI dency of material force. and because it led him
be despise positive rules, the long violation Of whie
de will not remain unpunished.


nv "When pride was hurryng Napoleon towards b
r., fall, he happened to say: France has more need


me than l have of France He spoke the trut


But why had he become necessarily Because


had committed the destiny Of the French to Il
- chances of an interminable war; because, in spin
I'D of the resources oits genius, rendered ds
st ly more hazardous by his stalking the whole OF II
he force and by the bodne of his movements, risk


in every campaign in every battle, the frui
